awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Fully Integrated Power and Energy Systems with Multi-Infeed AC/DC Architecture: Developing Advanced Controls, Protections, and Hardware-In-the-Loop Simulati
awd_abstract_narration:
The U.S. Department of Energy defines the microgrid as a group of interconnected loads and distributed energy resources within clearly defined electrical boundaries that acts as a single controllable entity with respect to the grid; it can connect to and disconnect from the grid to enable it to operate in both grid-connected or island-mode. The modernized microgrid (MG) mimics large power systems, but it has its own characteristics which must be effectively addressed. In this project, fully integrated power and energy system (FIPES) concept will be introduced and investigated as a new trend in the integration of MGs. The FIPES-based MGs will be able to supply a high power, including more flexibility in loads, improve power quality, and will be able to integrate an increased number of battery energy storage systems (BESSs) to benefit from their dynamic response and/or energy arbitrage. This research develops advanced MG's protections, controls, and automation and helps them merge into one single process. The developed theories of this project can be tailored and broadly developed for many networked-type of systems in other domains, including control engineering applications; advanced naval power systems; communication-based automated energy systems; multi-agent systems; and process control systems. Moreover, the hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) simulation systems enhanced here can be broadly utilized. The project will give specific attention to the involvement of underrepresented minorities at Georgia Southern University and Mississippi State University in STEM research and learning. They will be engaged in multidisciplinary topics in modernized power grids with renewables' integration. The project developments will be used to enhance public knowledge through outreach programs and public presentations. Improvement of existing and development of new STEM curriculum topics will be given close consideration.

This proposal performs fundamental investigations into synthesis and development of robust and advanced control algorithms, protection schemes, and simulation methodologies for a fully integrated power and energy system (FIPES) concept as the future trend in an MG. This fundamental research will be based on high penetration of fast, bidirectional power electronic converters to fully integrate renewables and BESSs in a multi-infeed ac/dc architecture. Here, the control, stability, performance, and protection objectives are closely tied and shall be addressed integrally by adopting advanced power electronic devices. This research also considers the power quality, in addition to fault-tolerance aspects, and will also investigate and address the associated cybersecurity concerns via an innovative approach that models cyberattacks through fault-tolerant systems. The architectural complexity and components diversity yield to a highly complex dynamical system where the conventional linear approaches are not competitive enough to address the required objectives. They need to be addressed by developing advanced nonlinear and robust approaches which are also able to take into account the coupling dynamics; frequency-variable conditions; and fast, tight time-constants. Therefore, the power system's design and performance goals will be achieved at lower hardware capacities and requirements using hybrid ac/dc structure. This project will thus address those aspects by developing robust, advanced control and protection systems for FIPES-based MGs using an approach that consists of integrating multiple dynamics and deploying nonlinear, dynamical systems theories. Control-/power-hardware-in-the-loop (C/PHIL) testing and digital real-time simulations will be utilized to assess the functionality of proposed control philosophies and protection schemes. As regards the stability and performance of PHIL testing, new improved PHIL methods will be proposed accordingly.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project dealt with energy systems including renewable generators combined with battery energy storage systems which use power electronic interfaces. Methodologies and solutions for controlling the interactions among such energy systems and the hosting utility grid were devised, analyzed, and tested. 

In one aspect, the project investigated the possibility of using distributed battery energy storage systems to introduce inertia into the dynamics of a power system. Such inertia, when adjusted properly, is able to maintain the voltage of the system across its various nodes when a disturbance occurs. Thus, the work developed a controller to accomplish this objective. 

The increased penetration of solar photovoltaic (PV) generators in many power grids causes a phenomenon called the duck curve phenomenon. The net load profile of the system will have a duck shape due to the daily pattern of solar intensity. As a result, the profile will have a steep rise during late afternoon and early evening hours with possibly an increased peak. It can even have a low peak during the peak PV hours. Thus, the project proposed a solution in which the distributed battery energy storage systems are linked with PV generators. The solution was shown to be able to address all three aspects of the duck curve (steep rise, increased peak in the evening, low peak during day) without requiring the batteries to use a communication infrastructure.

The fast-changing output power of PV generators caused by cloud movements was also addressed by using the same battery energy storage systems. The battery absorbs and releases energy quickly in response to those disturbances to mitigate their adverse effects on the system. The study of storage sizing according to the desired response specifications was also performed in this project.

Deploying autonomous battery energy storage systems, i.e. when the battery is not necessarily co-located with a PV generator, in order to improve power quality was investigated in the project and a solution mechanism was proposed. The battery system detects the system disturbances via their signature on the locally measured voltage. Then, through an advanced controller that provides both a static and a dynamic support to the grid, it will counter the disturbance. As a result, the entire system voltage profile will be enhanced. 

The project also proved that the dc capacitor voltage of a power electronic interface does not have to be tightly regulated, as it is the common practice. Indeed, such practice does compromise the stability margins of the converter. Therefore, the project proposed a solution where the dc capacitor voltage is allowed to slightly vary within a pre-specified acceptable range in linear proportion to the converter power. It was mathematically proven that this will significantly improve the system stability margins.

In all aspects of the project, professional simulation models reflecting the practical conditions were developed. Furthermore, laboratory-scale experimental setups were built to test the proposed solutions.

A number of journal and conference publications were presented to disseminate the findings of the project. Multiple graduate students were engaged in the project and received direct supervision and guidance from the PI to improve their analytical, research, and hands-on skills. Some of these students have already joined the insutry.
